newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: KL shares end higher as Iraq news shrugged off.
newsitem.headline: KL shares end higher as Iraq news shrugged off.

text.p: Share prices bounced from Tuesday's skid as players shrugged off a second U.S. missile attack on Iraq, traders said.

After initial caution, players returned to the buying side as Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has retaliated only with words. "There's renewed confidence as the confrontation was not as severe as initially thought," said Victor Wan, senior analyst at South Johore Securities.
The benchmark Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange Composite Index ended up 12.10 points or 1.11 percent to 1,105.42. The index fell 12.88 points on Tuesday.
Blue chips which returned to the black include Telekom, Tanjong, Maybank, UMW and Proton which gained between 15 and 50 cents.
Punters also resumed their activities on secondaries, driving the Second Board index up 19.43 points to 542.00.
Speculative buying pushed up stocks linked to businessman Vincent Tan, traders said. Top gainer Unza jumped 6.05 to 26.25 ringgit on asset reshuffling rumours.
Other Tan-linked counters which jumped include Bridgecon, Berjaya Group, Berjaya Industrial and Hospital Pantai, rising between 16 cents and 1.40 ringgit.
